title: Can mankind cease to exist? - Quora

response.answer_text: “What is the most likely thing to wipe humanity out as of right now?” Whatever the most likely thing is to destroy humanity, its probability is close to 0. Why? Complex animals have been around for over 500 million years. In all that time, nothing has wiped out all the animals. Even the huge asteroid that hit the Earth 65 million years ago, that killed off the dinosaurs, ended up allowing mammals to flourish. Here is the single most important reason why it would be virtually impossible for humans to be killed off: we inhabit almost every part of the Earth that is habitable. This makes virtually impossible to wipe out everyone. Let’s get specific. Overpopulation Below is a graph of projected human population. As can be seen, we’ll top out from at around 10 billion people, up from the current 7.6 billion. There’s more than enough room and resources for 10 billion people.  In many developed countries under-population is a big problem. The following is actually true: Japan sells more adult diapers than baby diapers. Natural Resources Because of the continued exponential growth in technology, we have access to more natural resources than ever before. Fracking has allowed countries to inexpensively obtain more natural gas than we thought possible. Technological advances have also allowed us to inexpensively tap into more oil reserves than before. We will not run out of these fossil fuels before we don’t need them to generate energy anymore. Resources such as aluminum, iron, manganese, chromium, etc., never get used up - they don’t leave the Earth. With advances in technology and robotics, we’ll be able to recycle these and never run out of them. Similarly, water never leaves the Earth. It just takes technology and energy to make it potable. Energy Renewable energy is getting less expensive every month. We’ll also need a steady baseload of energy. The only source of a clean baseload of energy right now is nuclear power. It is a bit expensive right now, but within 10 to 20 years, it should be competitive with natural gas or coal. This means that by around 2050, any new energy plants should be non-polluting and non-greenhouse gas emitting. Which leads to our next topic. Global Warming Are humans causing the Earth to warm? Yes. By how much? Here’s a graph from NASA for you that has actual data, not projections from the hundreds of climate models:  Note that the dates start from 1979, about when we could accurately make projections because we’ve had good satellite data since then. The red line is the running average. Starting at 1980 and going to 2017, we’ve increased by about +0.41C in that 37 year period. Let’s extrapolate that over a century. It comes out to a 1.2C increase by 2100. Other graphs show a bit higher, but they all show less than a 2C increase by the year 2100. Since we’ll have clean energy, and energy that emits no greenhouse gasses before this century is over, there is not a chance that global warming will cause human extinction. Disease There is no conceivable epidemic that could wipe out humanity. As mentioned above, we are spread all over the Earth. With modern sanitation, the CDC, the WHO, quarantine, etc., no disease is likely to kill a significant portion of the developed world. Less developed countries would suffer more, as they have been, but not enough to make a significant dent in their population. Artificial Intelligence If some very bad people send up drones, or automated jets, or automated cars or trucks, they could do much damage. But this would not be a threat to humanity. What if AIs became conscious and decided to wipe out humanity? Yes, some scientists are actually concerned about this. Here’s the good news. No one has any idea as to how to create self-aware machines. Watching too many Terminator movies is the cause of this fear. Nuclear War The chances of a major nuclear war are very small. Only the United States and Russia have over a thousand nuclear warheads. Neither country wants to die. But even if they did have a major nuclear war, it would certainly be devastating, but most of humanity would survive. (The fallout from a nuclear war is pretty minimal because the blasts are made above the Earth to achieve the greatest blast radius. This means not much soil will be irradiated). A few nukes from North Korea or Iran, while being terrible to those areas that are hit, will not make a dent in human population. A Giant Asteroid This, I think, is the biggest threat to humanity. A hit from a 20 mile wide asteroid might cause human extinction, if only because the result may cause the sky to darken for years. But the odds of such an asteroid hitting the Earth are millions to 1 in a given year. By next century, we should have the means to detect and then deflect these killer asteroids.  Humans are here to stay We’ll be here until the Sun burns out in a few billion years. The important question is: Are we going to use our talents to create an Enlightened Civilization? I trust that this will be the case.

The question is, “How will our existence end?” Your existence and mine, in the physical sense, will end when we have died and decomposed. The existence of the human race will end when the last individual member of the species dies. This could happen tomorrow, if all of the existing weapons of war were set loose. It will more likely be hundreds of thousands or even millions of years in the future, under circumstances we cannot currently imagine. The earth will eventually become cold and barren, unable to support life, before it is consumed by the sun, in a billion years or so. The observable universe may continue to exist forever, but the current understanding of physics indicates that it will probably, after many billions of years, either collapse into a fireball (or else a black hole) or expand into a lifeless void. Existence itself has no end. The existence of our souls—if we accept the existence of the soul—also has no end: And now concerning thy question regarding the soul of man and its survival after death. Know thou of a truth that the soul, after its separation from the body, will continue to progress until it attaineth the presence of God, in a state and condition which neither the revolution of ages and centuries, nor the changes and chances of this world, can alter. It will endure as long as the Kingdom of God, His sovereignty, His dominion and power will endure. It will manifest the signs of God and His attributes, and will reveal His loving kindness and bounty. —Gleanings from the Writings of Bahá’u’lláh, number LXXXI. Thou art My dominion and My dominion perisheth not; wherefore fearest thou thy perishing? Thou art My light and My light shall never be extinguished; why dost thou dread extinction? Thou art My glory and My glory fadeth not; thou art My robe and My robe shall never be outworn. Abide then in thy love for Me, that thou mayest find Me in the realm of glory. —The Hidden Words, Arabic, number 14. The reason for this is that the soul, unlike the body, the earth, and the observable universe, is not a composition: Every composition is necessarily subject to destruction or disintegration. For instance, this flower is a composition of various elements; its decomposition is inevitable. When this composed form undergoes decomposition—in other words, when these elements separate and disintegrate—that is what we call the death of the flower. For inasmuch as it is composed of single elements, the grouping of multitudinous cellular atoms, it is subject to disintegration. This is the mortality of the flower. Similarly, the body of man is composed of various elements. This composition of the elements has been given life. When these elements disintegrate, life disappears, and that is death. Existence in the various planes, or kingdoms, implies composition; and nonexistence, or death, is decomposition. But the inner and essential reality of man is not composed of elements and, therefore, cannot be decomposed. It is not an elemental composition subject to disintegration or death. A true and fundamental scientific principle is that an element itself never dies and cannot be destroyed for the reason that it is single and not composed. Therefore, it is not subject to decomposition. —The Promulgation of Universal Peace, talk number 123, given on 9 November 1912. The following answers provide further considerations relevant to this question: Robert Harris's answer to What is the actual destiny of every human in this world?Robert Harris's answer to Is humanity a failed experiment?Robert Harris's answer to What if the world is always "reset" after humanity reaches a certain point? Humans reach a point where "God" intervenes and destroys everything or we destroy ourselves to the point of losing our history and knowledge.Robert Harris's answer to Can religion be the most likely cause of extinction for humanity?Robert Harris's answer to Do you believe that immortality would be good for humanity? Why?Robert Harris's answer to Does time as we know it have a beginning or an end? Or is it infinite and endless?

There are a lot of possibilities of how humanity can be wiped out. Genetic engineering. It would be quite possible for scientists to create some disease that would be incurable, highly contagious, and fatal to 100% of the people who get the disease. It would also be possible for them to engineer something that caused all crops to fail leading to mass starvation. It would also be possible for them to engineer something that destroyed the ecosystem in other ways.AI. Computers are getting smarter and smarter. Someday soon everything in the world will be connected and artificial intelligence will get smarter and smarter until it is far more intelligent than humans. Someday these computers could be smart enough to decide they don’t need humans sucking up all the resources and telling them what to do and decide to obliterate us.Nuclear weapons. The world has used a lot of restraint when it comes to nuclear weapons but should some crazed third world ruler decide to start the weapons flying it could spread to the point where the world is destroyed.Population growth. World population grows faster and faster. Like it or not we are leaches or more correctly fungus that suck the life out of the earth. We deplete the soils, chop down the rain forests, pollute the air and water and destroy the world we live in in many ways. With population growing at the current rate in another generation or two we will not have the capability to feed the population of the world. As we continue to destroy our planet we could get it to the point where life can not be sustained.Climate change. I have never been a big believer in climate change but I do notice our weather seems much more extreme than in the past. It seems like every night when I turn on the news I see reports of floods, forest fires, mud slides, sink holes and other extreme weather. What I see on today’s news may just be a harbinger of things to come.Of course there is always a chance of a comet hitting the Earth or the sun exploding or the earth spinning out of orbit or biblical style floods or any of a million possible natural disasters.I will be surprised if the earth is a peaceful comfortable place packed with happy human animals in two or three centuries. I think human life is most likely in it’s waning days but the chances are when humankind no longer exists the cause will be something we never could have forecast. I won’t be around to see it and to know but I do wish mankind the best.

Climate Change. And don't take my word for it: Final defense policy bill mandates Pentagon climate change study Climate change threatens half of U.S. military sites: Pentagon Effects of Climate Change | Threats | WWF Why is China’s smog so bad? Researchers point far away to a melting Arctic Here's the simplest way I can explain it: every species and society has a sort of “Goldilocks zone” to them — the Earth is just far away from the sun to not be scorched dry, and not be deathly cold either… but on Earth, each creature has adapted to a specific place, without having to make and wear specific clothing for protection, or get food outside of where they live. Humans are a bit more complicated because we're flexible like that, but you still can't expect people to live in volcanoes or deep underwater for very long, because we still have our basic needs based on what we are: biological meat bags with sentience. When things change, it becomes harder for humans to survive. But it depends mostly on how fast the change is: a fast change like war is difficult to survive in, but natural climate change is normally slow enough that we can do something about it in our own time. Not anymore though. Climate change (specifically, Global Warming) as we know it today, is when the seasons and normal average weather patterns change: hotter summers, colder winters, and even the timing of each season changes resulting in late springs and early winters. And because our society depends on the weather and seasons being stable — our crops, our plans, our entire species as a whole suffers. Nevermind how such changes become blessings to the various insects and microbes that force people to use poisons and antibiotics on, killing even more wildlife and people, while teaching the mocrobes how to overcome antibiotics as a result of their overuse (out of fear for the microbes affecting crops). Nevermind the effects these would have on methane trapped in permafrost, or in melted ice diluting the oceans, making it harder for Earth to recover from the damage caused by runaway development. And the cycle only gradually continues to accelerate to a point where entire Earth can no longer sustain life. It's already happening, with deserts expanding and crops failing to grow in certain regions. As a result of the already-existing threats of reduced land area and supplies, people have become more violent and desperate. It's not surprising if this would fuel all the existing wars into a full-blown series of disasters. Climate change alone won't kill humanity. But it is such a powerful amplifier of everything that can kill us (weather, disease, famine, violence, war), that it might very well be the number one real method for initiating an Everyone Dies™ scenario. Climate change doesn't kill people. People kill people… when they take climate change and pull the trigger that causes it to blow up into disastrous proportions.

I already know how tge world will end, but I will entertain this question with the most likely scenarios if it weren’t the case, and I will tell you how the world will end at the end of the answer. Now, these are not just the most likely ones to end humanity, but probably the only ones: . Mega-subterrestrial explosion, which would launch lots of debris into the atmiaphere causing climate chanve too severe and too sudden to survive. Or asteroid collision with Earth (we barely dodged one a few years ago). Which would have the same effect. Or just hit hard enough to cause massive earthquakes… lemme clarify. Even with what we consider massive earthquakes, humanity might still survive, even if it is just a few thousand people that survive. I am talking tectonic plates overlaping massive earthquakes. Planet shape shifting massive earthquakes. That kind of stuff would exterminate us. Any less, humanity coukd survive. And an asteroid would have that effect, or the same as the mega-subterrestrial explosion. Depending on the size of the asteroid. All out sudden worldwide nuclear war. Like, all the nuclear bombs fired at the same time. Only like 0.01% of the population would survive the explosions and fallout. But, severe sudden climate change. Solar flare. Because severe sudden climate change. After 50% of the Earth has been completely incinerated and 25% has been scorched. . Then again… the severe sudden climate climate change already happened, and some animals survived. So, maybe even that wouldn’t. Of these, I think asteroid hit and sub-terrestrial mega explosion would be most likely. . We could survive disease, we could survive many things. Now how the world will end. And lemme telk ya, its not too far. . God will destroy the world. He will save the wholehearted Christians and will create a new world where we will live happily ever after.

Throughout the ages there have been catastrophic variations of The Four Horsemen and our own era is no exception. And we are still here. The truth is, it takes an awful lot to kill everybody all at once, even if 99% of the present population suddenly died, millions will remain. Within the zone of 'total' destruction, right under the Hiroshema bomb, there were some survivors. Ghengiz Khan's army, on the other hand, managed to kill each and every man, woman and child, plus all their animals, in one day, in a city refusing to submit to him, with just swords and arrows. It's not just about the level of technology. This is not the same as saying our species will remain long term. We have been on the Earth an insignificant fraction of its existence, most of which were in conditions completely poisonous to human life. Climate change is ongoing and always has been . . . Large asteroid collisions have occurred regularly, although none as yet during our brief page of time . . . We are currently on top of killer diseases but we won't know about the next ones until they come along . . . During recent centuries, the output of the Sun, within its various cycles, has remained tolerably constant, this may not always be true . . . . . . and there are, no doubt, 'unknown unknowns'.

Starvation. It’s the oldest threat. Climate change destroys crops and rearranges supply lines. It moves some crops north. It kills pasturage. It rearranges rainfall. The Sahara desert was once fertile savannah, supporting billions of species. Today, climate change has reduced this fertile land to barren sand. The American heartland, the greatest producer of food in history, is running out of water because of climate change. The rain isn’t falling, and the deserts of the Midwest are expanding. It is easy to imagine an American Sahara stretching from Memphis to Seattle. As humans decline into a threatened species as a result of climate change, they will also become more susceptible to disease. The further north you are, the less effective the atmosphere is at blocking UV rays from the sun. Those UV rays kill bacteria in the air and on exposed surfaces. Currently, cold temps in the north keep bacteria in check. With climate warming, the bacteria are no longer refrigerated and the UV can’t kill them off. Expect the final survivors of humanity to die from staphylococcus infections. You youngsters have about 100 years to stop this. I’m too old, and I’ll be gone before it kills you. You can start at the ballot box. Elect educated, intelligent leaders, unlike the bunch of fools we have now. You might have a chance.

I don’t know if there is such a thing as an expert for such a question but here goes. Surely a pandemic, a virus or whatever, that we cannot find a treatment for can travel around the planet, spread by air. One other is a big rock from space smashes into the earth. Lots of movies on this topic and currently a TV show on Netflix called “Salvation”. I will not get into zombies though as I am sure they are real fiction. The rock and the pandemic - believable. If I was a living dinosaur I'd be looking up a lot. Just thought of this so am adding as an edit. This is real and happening. ALL THE BEES DIE. Now which is most likely? I pick 2 winners: the bees and the rock.

Life on earth is protected by a geomagnetic field which “is becoming weaker; the present strong deterioration corresponds to a 10–15% decline over the last 150 years and has accelerated in the past several years; geomagnetic intensity has declined almost continuously from a maximum 35% above the modern value achieved approximately 2,000 years ago. The rate of decrease and the current strength are within the normal range of variation, as shown by the record of past magnetic fields recorded in rocks.” When it runs out in a thousand years of so, we all die. We’ll probably all die if it flips as evolutionist claim happened about 300,000 years ago, but evidence for that is actually evidence of tectonic activity during Noah’s flood. On the other hand, WW3 might happen before then, if we haven’t all died before hand from pollution of our soil, food, water and air. God’s ways work best. Too bad so few of us are willing to love others as He loves us.

The question is a bit vague, but here is an answer nobody has thought of, although billions and billions are being spent on making it happen right now. Happiness Box Collapse. A “Happiness Box” is a box you put your brain into, and a computer generates a virtual Paradise for your. Without a body to get sick, you could live for thousands of years. A Russian billionaire named Dmitry Itskov who wants to live forever is working on the brain-in-a-box part. The video game industry is developing the software. Herewith an article that describes the process in more rigorous detail: LIVE FOREVER IN A HAPPINESS BOX AND NEVER DIE https://futurism.media/live-fore... I estimate the first commercial Happiness Boxes will be available within 30–50 years. Hmm, it occurs to me I’m assuming Dmitry will never have any help. That’s probably wrong. I suppose as more and more people saw the potential, they would start pouring in more money, until in the end the brain-in-a-box project will be spending just as much money as the video game industry. The end result will be the total extinction of the human race, of course, but nobody’s going to care about that. Jeff Corkern -------------------------------------------------- Consider the following as a statement of logic, and rank it as "True" or "False": "If people possess immortal souls, it should be possible to logically deduce this by objective analysis of their actions." http://www.theninepointfivetheses.blogspot.com

A big ole rock. pandemics might take out 50 or even 90% of us. nuclear weapons the same. If stupidity would do it, it would have done it already. But…. we pretend like we know so much but we don’t see all the big rocks coming. I’ve read more than a few instances of large rocks (big enough to end us) being discovered only days or weeks from passing close. We don’t yet have the ability to destroy or divert. 65 million years is a really really long lucky streak. Big question is once it’s discovered does our government tell us for fear of the panic that would ensue. My guess is nope.

Scientific perspective: Yes, all humans cease to exist forever and ever, unless our future selves can harness the energy to allow space crafts to travel at speeds of light and faster to get to other planets, than, we can live there on those other planets, but even then, nothing will last forever, it doesn't matter what humans do, we will die, cease to exist, even the universe itself, ok, even an afterlife will perish, but before that, you and I will cease to exist the moment our brain shuts down, completely, our conscoiusness will forever cease to exist, but there will be no worries though, because to worry would imply you have conscoiusness, so not having conscoiusness would equal no more worries, hope I made sense? Spiritual perspective: Yes, all humans will cease to exist, but only in this reality, once brain dead, your soul, (“you”) will venture off into wherever it is that you originated from but that can only happen once your entire brain (biological computer) ceases functioning, than your soul or “you" will transcend, your consciousness will never cease to exist

An airborne virus. Most of the nastiest epidemics in the past have been passed on by physical contact and so their reach is limited. In the case of airborne viruses we now live in a world where air travel is so ubiquitous that a single person can infect say 450 people on a single aeroplane. Those 450 people go on to take connecting flights. In a very short space of time there is a pandemic. Depending on how lethal the virus is, or how it mutates, it could wipe out, probably not all of humanity, but enough people to change our world as we know it. On the other hand, if the current coronavirus wiped out 5 billion people, although that is a huge number, it would merely take us back to the world population of the 1960’s.

Of course. Everything ceases to exist sooner or later, except possibly the universe itself, and even that may. If we defy all the odds against our survival, achieve peace among ourselves, learn environmental sanity, and everything else that is wholly beneficial to perpetually sustainable life on our lovely planet, we’re still doomed. Our own sun will betray us in a few billion years when it runs out of enough fuel to sustain main sequence. It will balloon out into a red giant, burning this planet to a cinder and then consuming the cinder. But the larger probability is that a collision with nice fat asteroid or comet will wipe us out long before then. Nothing lasts forever.

As far as we know, the universe will likely be unable to sustain life forever. There are multiple ways in which this can happen, including the big rip and heat death theories. The former theory says that, if dark matter happens to accelerate in a certain way, the universe will tear itself apart. According to the theory’s original authors, this may occur about 22 billion years from now. The latter theory, which is slightly more plausible, assumes that if our current understanding of heat entropy is correct, that heat energy will be so spread out across the universe that life will be unsustainable. Of course, it is unlikely that humanity could survive long enough for either of those fates to matter. Nuclear war and the death of our sun are both much more imminent threats that could easily wipe us out, not to mention potential universal deaths that we are yet unaware of.

A rather virulent strain of the common flu. Many people forget the great flu epidemic of the last century. Killed about 5-10% of all humanity - and this was only 100 years ago. Where people had the concept of virus, bacteria, etc. It is way more likely we’ll be wiped out by a pandemic than anything else. Even a nuclear war would likely leave some people alive. Not just me that thinks this also: Bill Gates thinks an infectious disease outbreak could kill 30 million people at some point in the next decade — here’s how worried you should be

My highest concern is the effect of air travel on diseases. Not just in terms of rapid transmission across the globe, but also the environment inside the plane and what it does to humans. Do you know how many people are above the stratosphere at any given time? It’s 3 million. With all their bugs. Do you know how many miles you have to travel to equal the reccommended LIFETIME dose of mutation-causing radiation? See the maths here: Air travel exposes you to radiation – how much health risk comes with it? Now, there’s plenty there to take issue with, and it’s only describing fatal cancer risks: but bugs have DNA too. By all means pooh-pooh this, but not until you have read the last 3 lines of the long table of sunspot data, here: Yearly Mean Sunspot Numbers We have been flying around like idiots, right through one of the most intense sunspot periods of recorded human history. Sunspots turbocharge the radiation dose you will get when you rise above the protection of the lower atmosphere.

Most likely a return of our natural predators - microorganisms. A new disease could easily wipe out fifty percent (50%) of the human population, perhaps more. A really clever disease would raise that number to 90 percent - returning Planet Earth to a relatively safe scenario with enough people to properly support / maintain it. Then there is the possibility of a meteorite / asteroid. That would be pretty spectacular. Or we could just continue to damage our environment - our habitat. I suspect it will be the last noted here - global warming.

I don't think it would be nuclear war or a supervolcanic eruption as although extremely serious there would be many humans left unscathed . But a strike from a reasonable sized asteroid could destroy humanity the way it is believed the dinosaurs. The impact from such an object has far greater destructive power than anything man has or caused by an eruption. These are monitored and trajectory tracked constantly for anything that could be potentially destructive , but the present belief is we could do little to prevent it.

If we don't end it all in a nuclear war then I feel like there's only a certain amount of time before we become overpopulated and food supply isn't enough. This paired with the ice caps melting and apparently releasing tons of carbon dioxide into the atmosphere which I hear is incredibly catastrophic. I feel like the atmosphere disappearing should be a legitimate concern for being taken out. Not to mention Fukushima is still leaking tons of radiation into the oceans every year and they still haven't found a way to take the fuel rods out. Whenever most ocean life dies that's also pretty catastrophic just based off my assumption. Considering humans caused all of this then yes humans will cause our own demise.

The most likely thing to kill a lot of people is definitely climate change. However, I don’t know that it is likely to kill everyone. Still, climate change would be my answer — but since others have thought of this, here is another possible answer: a large meteor hitting the Earth. Ok, so is it likely to happen? Not as far as we know. But we don’t know much. Will it happen eventually? Yes. Would we have any warning? Maybe yes or maybe not. It’s not so easy to see . Could we do something about it? Almost definitely not. And a large enough meteor would be an extinction level event.

First of all please know that I am not an expert or a learned person in this subject however I have read all 17 of the answers currently posted and agree with most of them except for a couple of the nut job answers. An answer from Joseph Schwartzman refers to bees and I would like to elaborate. The loss of bees may seem like a minor problem but I live in an agricultural part of the US and see how active the bees are in the spring and summer, going from one bloom to the next, constantly. These bees are carrying the promise of continued renewal of the plant and without bees there will be no renewal or produce made by the plant/tree. I would guess without bees the human race would have about 4 years to live. One small polination for a bee, one giant polination for the human race.

Soylent Green IS people. People have been wiping out people, plants, animals, etc… forever. So people, and human society, and stupidity. Whether a gun, a sword, a bomb, gas, germ warfare, WHATEVER is used. It matters not. It will be PEOPLE. As George Carlin said: The Earth will shrug us off like dirt. Now we, we can destroy ourselves. Not the Earth. PEOPLE. Who cares how? Dead is dead.

Thank you for the A2A Anton Gäverström. Ignorance! Thinking we can beat the forces of nature and control the fate of us. And that mentality gets duplicated by thousands of small decisions that add up to a considerable whole. Like how we lost life skills like farming and primary production because of the creation of a a desired urban, city life. [1] Like how health programmes are working against their original intentions. [2] Like how palm oil plantations are changing and weakening the ecosystem. [3] Plus too many are willing to keep quiet lest it threatens our way of current living. And all it takes for bad things to happen is for good people to keep quiet and look the other way. [4] Footnotes[1] Rural development in need of an integrated approach to agriculture[2] Health programmes ‘victim’ of dengue vaccine scam[3] Palm oil is destroying the planet and killing animals - and it's in almost everything[4] Edmund Burke Quotes

By far the biggest threat to humanity is nuclear weapons. It's not even remotely close. Nuclear weapons are hundreds if not thousands of times more likely to kill you than anything else listed in other answers. Unfortunately it could happen at any given moment, and there's not a thing anyone on this fucking planet could do about it even if they wanted to.

I hope that, in the space between now and our extinction, hopefully by the death of our star, The Sun, we humans will find a way to travel to other far solar systems, wich can be situated on the nearby surroundings or far away maybe thousands of light years. That can be achieved by syntethizing our DNA into bynary code (wich was already made by John Craig Venter) and provide an organic soup on arrival so we can rebirth there.

What is the most likely thing to wipe humanity out as of right now? Stupidity. Human stupidity to be specific. We are so dumb and constantly try to experiment with things like biological weapons. My guess is that something like this will get loose or used by someone who bought for very little and it will kill a lot of people.

We what KNOW for CERTAIN ! what will wipe out humanity ! Our Sun will eventually use up all its stock of of Hydrogen and start to burn Helium . The laws of Physics say that this will mean that The Sun will expand so much that Earth will be INSIDE the Sun ! But LONG before it gets to that point the heat will have incinerated us ! But don’t worry yet ! this will not even start to happen for another 10 Million years !

The most likely thing to wipe out humanity right now is a virus that turns everyone into a zombie cannibal or one that makes everyone infertile. Even an all out nuclear war and/or a major pandemic cannot be guaranteed to wipe all of humanity out.

if you think of existence and the end of the body, the answer is obvious- death! I propose a different perspective- existence is that which is, before any concept arises and traps the mind into thinking. Existence cannot not be- it is positive, powerful, immutable, ‘in your face’; it has always been- eternal, beyond space and time, never changing. It is obvious when thoughts like death, life, existence, non-existence… entertained by the mind are simply ignored- of course any thought report to the chief thought ‘I’ which needs make no exception from any other concept to be ignored. Through practice the mind becomes weaker and the background of existence upon which any thought arises will ‘swap places’ with the fascination for thoughts and become the foreground of reality that is your true nature.

Humans will cease to exist when machine-based intelligence eclipses biologically-based intelligence. Kurt Weil describes this as the “singularity” in his book, “The Singularity is Near”. Just as artificial hearts, arms and legs (prosthetics) replace their counterparts, so will artificial brains replace theirs, largely without any fuss or bother, and with far greater efficiency, longevity, and capability. Uploading a person’s entire personality and consciousness will become not only commonplace but also desirable. The last biologically-based intelligence will fade out as the last of the humans choose not to participate in their own evolution. Spoiler alert: this evolution is happening right now; we are happily inviting it, accepting it, and no one is wasting time looking back.

I doubt that it will be from a micro-organism/pandemic as we have developed techniques for fighting these - although they may well cause considerable havoc. We appear to have another four or five billion years before our star/sun kills all life on Earth, so there is plenty of time for us to either naturally evolve or be genetically engineered into a new species that will have fewer (or none) of the self-lethal aspects of H. sap. and which will eventually replace us because of its enhanced abilities to survive and reproduce while we continue to commit species suicide.

Yes. It is known via the bible that at a particular time, in the future that the human experiment will end.
